title: Did the Industrial Revolution improve life in Great Britain? - Quora

response.answer_text: I suppose it depends on your perspective, or at least the perspective of the people of the time. Undoubtedly it brought great wealth to those who were in a position to exploit the opportunities. This gave advantage to the landowners and those with investment money. For the remainder it was a more nuanced picture. Traditional jobs became mechanised and far fewer manual labourers were required. This caused a movement of people from agricultural to urban settings, whereby the towns expanded to meet the needs of the increasing number of manufacturing enterprises. In this case the people were often in poor housing in their old life with limited income and short life expectancy. The move to overcrowded tenements in towns made for different problems but this was often associated with increasing income. On balance they were probably marginally better off when they arrived in their chosen industry. This last group were the largest and the fact that they themselves felt better off once settled is the primary reason why Marx’ and Engels’ prediction that the proletariat would first rise in revolution in England simply failed to be realised. The skilled artisan who was steadily being out produced by factories and mills were the worst off. Their income was generally reduced and often they had been forced to penury or labouring. Cottage industries could not compete. Those who fell into this group mostdefinitely did not benefit from the Industrial Revolution. There is an oft forgotten aspect of the Industrial Revolution that did provide great opportunities for those whose brain enabled them to organise and control. Managers had been almost unheard of prior to this period. Now a new middle class emerged, those who had skills to manage. They acquired better education, significantly increased their wealth and this group above all others found the Industrial Revolution was a life-changing opportunity and they benefitted greatly.

The Industrial Revolution saw the great age of steam, canals and factories which changed the face of the British economy forever in the 18th century and led to the emergence of what became the Capitalist Revolution.’ Early 18th century British industries were generally small scale and relatively unsophisticated. Most textile production, for example, was centred on small workshops or in the homes of spinners, weavers and dyers: a literal ‘cottage industry’ that involved thousands of individual manufacturers. Such small-scale production was also a feature of most other industries, with different regions specializing in different products: metal production in the Midlands, for example, and coal mining in the North-East. Because there were limited sources of power, industrial development during the early 1700s was initially slow. Textile mills, heavy machinery and the pumping of coal mines all depended heavily on old technologies of power: waterwheels, windmills and horsepower were usually the only sources available. Changes in steam technology, however, began to change the situation dramatically. As early as 1712 Thomas Newcomen first unveiled his steam-driven piston engine, which allowed the more efficient pumping of deep mines. Steam engines improved rapidly as the century advanced, and were put to greater and greater use. More efficient and powerful engines were employed in coalmines, textile mills and dozens of other heavy industries. By 1800 perhaps 2,000 steam engines were eventually at work in Britain. Yes. What is very little appreciated was how shit life was before the IR for poor folk. Every horror later commented on was there but few commented on it at the time: it was always and inevitable, so what’s to say? Later, as we moved into the Victorian period in North West Europe, it became clear that at least some of the horrors could be avoided and people campaigned for improvement. That’s why we become more aware of the problems. By the by, the term “Industrial Revolution’, created by French historians to contrast with the French Revolution and popularised in the 18sos in English by Arnold Toynbee is really misleading. Over a period of decades not only did industry change but so did: transport, finance, education, literature, sport and all aspects of life, due to the sustained economic boom. If we called the 18th century boom few people would ask your question. For details get my book : The Birth of Now https://www.amazon.co.uk/Birth-Now-Effect-Greatest-History/dp/1785891227

By the numbers, no. The benefits of economic takeoff - as opposed to the technological revolution that drastically altered the economic landscape - were not evenly distributed, so the overall benefit flowed towards the monied middle class and away from the common people. The drastic changes that befell rural economies and home-based industries alike led to the involuntary abandonment of the countryside, the destruction of the rural economy driving incapable paupers to the workhouse and the able poor to relocate entire families to industrial towns and cities. The term revolution has a rather different connotation in societies where revolution is not automatically assumed to be an unalloyed blessing. In the sense the Industrial Revolution disrupted families, devastated communities, created refugee communities obliged to live in squalid conditions in what to modern eyes would seem to be forced labour terms, it was well named. It would take centuries for the benefits to trickle down from the decision-makers to the peasants who unwillingly were obliged to become arguably the first proletariat, and the resulting democratic deficient is still deep and abiding. It is therefore ironic to witness the active misdirection that plays out even today, that seeks to imply society's ills can be cured by eliminating the aristocracy. Given they have played no active part in this process from its earliest beginnings, setting up in their place financiers, industrialists, with a cadre of career politicians that act - in effect - as their fawning uncritical courtiers, seems to have been misguided at best. And at worse that we have been the slack-jawed, dull-eyed victims of a succession of increasingly ham-fisted illusionists.

Air pollution went up, and death rates in London did, too. But the people who moved there chose to believing London life was better, so we can’t say it was irrational. The enclosure movement was driving some of it rather than London being wonderful. Overall though in most ways you can measure life improved over time for survivors: cheaper clothes with more variety, more varied food, more varied entertainment, more personal freedoms. People tend to ignore the poverty and early deaths from the period before, e.g. farm accidents, rural oppression, and the like.

Not really for the poor and those who did not own much at that time, but for the investors and those with wealth or property then yes. The process created wealth, a little of it trickled down, perhaps its fair to say it improved the quality of life for the following generations and today we are all better for it.
